content:
A feature we had in the Lean 3 import graph display was the ability to show modules which are not actually being used by the final node.

(Here "not actually being used" meant "no declaration in the final node makes transitive use of any declaration in the imported node".)
Would anyone be interested in restoring this functionality? It was super useful in understanding when transitive imports were unintentionally bringing too much in.

In the Lean 3 version, this was hidden behind a flag (although if it is cheap to run I would advocate making it on by default). It displayed unused imports by shading them grey. If no --to X.Y.Z target is specified, this should be turned off, because then there is an implicit --to Mathlib argument, which by design does not make use of any of its imports!
https://github.com/leanprover-community/import-graph/pull/27

Also two other lake exe graph PRs for review:

  • import-graph#26 changes the default so transitively redundant edges are not shown in the graph
  • import-graph#25 splits the --include-deps option to --include-deps, --include-std and --include-lean (all defaulting to false)
Is it easy to have some csv/json version of the output? For programmatic use dot/pdf aren't the handiest formats.

uncaught exception: Format: "csv" not recognized. Use one of: bmp canon cgimage cmap cmapx cmapx_np dot dot_json eps exr fig gd gd2 gif gv icns ico imap imap_np ismap jp2 jpe jpeg jpg json json0 kitty kittyz pct pdf pic pict plain plain-ext png pov ps ps2 psd sgi svg svg_inline svgz tga tif tiff tk vrml vt vt-24bit vt-4up vt-6up vt-8up wbmp webp xdot xdot1.2 xdot1.4 xdot_json

% lake exe graph --from Mathlib.RingTheory.Valuation.AlgebraInstances o.xdot_json
% cat o.xdot_json
{
  "name": "import_graph",
  "directed": true,
  "strict": false,
  "_subgraph_cnt": 0,
  "objects": [
    {
      "_gvid": 0,
      "name": "Mathlib.RingTheory.Valuation.AlgebraInstances",
      "label": "\\N"
    },
    {
      "_gvid": 1,
      "name": "Mathlib",
      "label": "\\N"
    }
  ],
  "edges": [
    {
      "_gvid": 0,
      "tail": 0,
      "head": 1
    }
  ]
}
Nice! How do we recognize a grey node in here?
Oh, that one doesn't have grey nodes, because it doesn't have a --to. I'll go make a nicer example.

lake exe graph --from Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Basic --to Mathlib.Analysis.LocallyConvex.Polar o.png

produces
o.png

lake exe graph --from Mathlib.SetTheory.Cardinal.Basic --to Mathlib.Analysis.LocallyConvex.Polar o.xdot_json

produces this.
It's a bit awkward, but I guess it does the job without any further code at the import-graph end of things. :-)
That's an impressive number of grey nodes

Yes, I'm a bit surprised. Perhaps it indicates that my algorithm is horribly wrong. :-) I challenge someone to either successfully "detach" one of these grey nodes, or demonstrate that my algorithm is wrong because it is impossible. :-)
I believe the left hand side, at least - only 7 declarations in Normed.Field.Basic use the grey deps
I promise this was a randomly chosen --to and --from pair. I did not go looking for anything particularly grey!
I've poked at it a bit, will likely continue later. Might help with the longest pole as well

Kim Morrison said:

https://github.com/leanprover-community/import-graph/pull/27

Also two other lake exe graph PRs for review:

  • import-graph#26 changes the default so transitively redundant edges are not shown in the graph
  • import-graph#25 splits the --include-deps option to --include-deps, --include-std and --include-lean (all defaulting to false)

I left comments on two of them and merged the third; @Kim Morrison if you're happy with the PRs I think it's fine if you merge them!

I don't think we have much quality standard on a tool like lake exe graph, do we? So if the unused-files algorithm isn't perfect yet, we can just fix it as people find cases where it's incorrect.

@Kim Morrison based on your example I've added another color-feature:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/import-graph/pull/28

I added a flag --mark-module which is supposed to be used in combination with --include-deps: It will highlight the current module, draw it much closer together and highlight all edges going into it. That might help actually looking at where external dependencies are used.

graph.pdf
Looks really nice!
I've acted on your suggestions, @Jon Eugster, and merged the open PRs.

If anyone is interested, I think a good feature would be to always show the direct imports of files from other libraries/lean, but not to show the transitive imports unless the relevant flags are on. This won't clutter the graphs much, but is very useful information for people to see how they are using other projects.

Kim Morrison said:

... to always show the direct imports of files from other libraries/lean, but not to show the transitive imports ...

https://github.com/leanprover-community/import-graph/pull/29

I added this to the --mark-module flag. I remember from the port that some people were annoyed when these first-degree-leaves were always-always on.

Feel free to modify that logic (and also rename --mark-module to something more sensible) :smile:

graph.png
graph.png

I did think about adding the Longest Pole as another feature (e.g. thick red arrows), but since Mathlib calculates this using speed center data instead of the longest import chain, I'm not sure if that makes sense...
Sometimes I see a thin white path in a cloud of gray nodes. How can I find out why A uses B?

What would be useful input/output for such a tool?

(The current solution, of course, being to remove some imports along that chain to see what breaks.)

Non-interactive:

  • the list of theorems/defs in file A that depend on something in file B;
  • the list of theorems/defs in file B required by something in file A.

The latter is useful if one wants to split file B into 2 parts (required by A, not required by A).
... so that A no longer depends on some file C which is needed for some theorems/defs in file B that aren't needed for file A.

So something like lake exe describe-deps A B?

It should be pretty easy to build this from existing components in import-graph.

(I'm not going to embark on this now, but I hope someone takes this up!)
Sorry if I'm missing something, but is there an (easy) way to generate a version of the import graph with only the white nodes shown?
@Felix Weilacher, do you mean deleting all the grey nodes, even if though they are transitively imported?
You could do this via lake exe graph --to X out.dot, munging the .dot files by hand to delete the relevant nodes, and then rendering via graphviz.
Or a PR to import-graph.
I'm slightly uncertain, in any case, what the use case for deleting the grey nodes is.

Yes, I ended up just modifying the dot file by hand.

The use case is that I want to have a nice visualization of the files a given file depends on.
Well, in that case you should work out how to remove the grey files from your imports, rather than just pretending they are not there. :-)
Because you do depend on them, just unnecessarily!
Well, mathlib has quite a lot of situations like this unfortunately
Let's fix them. :-)
I made the tool to show grey nodes, and scripts/unused_in_pole.sh <target> specifically to encourage people to identify and resolve these.
